questions.text: The organism causing the following disease is
questions.solution:
Hand, foot, and mouth disease is considered a self-limiting illness. It primarily affects infants and young children; however, it can also affect adolescents and adults. The hands, feet, and mouth are commonly affected, occasionally even the genitalia and buttocks are affected. HFMD is a viral exanthem. It is mostly caused by the coxsackievirus and enterovirus of the Enterovirus family.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1425

questions.text: A patient presented with ulcerative lesion on face after being bitten by an insect, as shown in the image. What can be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lesion commonly on face. Crusting in centre and scarring at periphery, Volcano sign

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1474

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with these lesions in the lumbosacral area. What is the cause for these lesions ?
questions.solution: Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-772

choices.text: Change in keratin from K5/14 to K1/10

questions.text: All of these are seen during keratinisation except
questions.solution:
• Changes seen during keratinisation
  1. Increase size of cell
  2. Flattening of cell
  3. Decrease in size of nucleus
  4. Progessive dehydration of cell
  5. Focussed metabolism

Change in keratin from K5/14 to K1/10

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.- 876

questions.text: Which of the following is used as nail lacquer for fungal infections?
questions.solution:
Terbinafine nail lacquer is used to treat onychomycosis

Lamisil(Terbinafine)?

Other nail laquers - amorolfine, ciclopirox, tavabirole, eficonazole

Reference: Akhtar N, Sharma H, Pathak K. Onychomycosis: Potential of Nail Lacquers in Transungual Delivery of Antifungals. Scientifica (Cairo). 2016;2016:1387936. doi: 10.1155/2016/1387936. Epub 2016 Mar 30. PMID: 27123362; PMCID: PMC4829734.

questions.text: All are true regarding the disease shown in the image except
questions.solution:
• Verruca vulgaris is caused by HPV I, 2, 27

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1393

questions.text: Stem cells in skin involved in skin homeostasis are present in the following areas except?
questions.solution:
• The stem cells of skin are present in 3 locations - basal layer of skin, bulge area in isthmus of hair follicle and the base of sebaceous glands

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-62

questions.text: A 5 years old girl presented with lesion on the face for the last 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathology of Molluscum contagiosum

  • Cup shaped lesion with inverted lobules of hyperplastic squamous epithelium which expand into the underlying dermis
  • Henderson-Paterson or molluscum bodies: large (up to 35 microns) intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies
  • At the granular layer, the bodies become increasingly hematoxyphilic and occupy the entire cell
  • Chronic inflammatory infiltrate seen in regressing lesions

Reference: Carrasquillo OY, Sanchez JL. Molluscum contagiosum. PathologyOutlines.com website. https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumormolluscum.html. Accessed December 20th, 2023.

questions.text: Oral candidiasis presents with white patch in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Types of Oral Candidiasis

Angular stomatitis: White plaques at angle of mouth (Perleche)

  • Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis (Thrush):
  • White erythematous plaques revealing erythematous base on removal
  • Seen on tongue, palate, gingiva, mucosa MC type of Candidiasis

Acute atrophic candidiasis: Patch de papillated areas on dorsal tongue

  • Chronic atrophic candidiasis: Sharply defined erythematous, edematous areas on plate (Denture mouth)

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.- 956

questions.text: A young adult presents with hypopigmented scaling macules over the back as seen in the following Image. Which drug is not used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis - Pityriasis versicolor
  • Griseofulvin is not effective in treatment.
  • Treatment options: Ketoconazole, fluconazole, itraconazole, selenium sulphide lotion, ciclopirox olamine lotion

Reference: Gupta AK, Foley KA. Antifungal Treatment for Pityriasis Versicolor. J Fungi (Basel). 2015 Mar 12;1(1):13-29. doi: 10.3390/jof1010013. PMID: 29376896; PMCID: PMC5770013.

questions.text: The following patient came with history of hair loss. There were no complaints of erythema, scarring and scratching. The dermoscopy image of the patient is shown below.Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Hair pulling tic, OCD
  • Young patient pull out own hair
  • Defined as the irresistible urge to pull out hair, accompanied by a sense of relief after it has been plucked
  • Alopecia patch with hair of different length in different directions
  • Broken hair with perifollicular haemorrhage also seen

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1175

questions.text: Bamboo hair as shown in the image below is seen in _____:
questions.solution:
• Netherton syndrome is a severe, autosomal recessive form of ichthyosis associated with mutations in the SPINK5 gene, leading to triad of a hair shaft defect (trichorrhexis invaginata,bamboo hair), atopic dermatitis and ichthyosis linearis circumflexa
  • Trichorrhexis nodosa is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily, leading to hair loss, lack of growth, and damaged-looking hair. It can be both congenital (AD) or aquired
  • Menkes kinky hair disease is a rare X-linked recessive disorder of copper-binding ATPase, ATP7A. intestinal copper uptake is normal, but copper transport to other tissues is affected. Scalp hair become hypopigmented, sparse, short, and brittle, skin pallor , hypothermia, tortuous arteries in brain, and progressive vascular changes in CNS leading to hypotonia, seizures and developmental delay

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-906

questions.text: Patient with pre-existing acne lesions was treated with long term antibiotics(tetracyclines). Developed papulo-pustules or nodules around nose and lips. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gram-negative folliculitis results from long-term antibacterial treatment in acne patients. It is caused by bacterial interference and replacement of the Gram-positive flora of the facial skin and the mucous membranes of the nose with Gram-negative bacteria like Escherischia coli, Klebsiella and Proteus mirabilis.

It should be considered in patients with acne who have a flare-up of pustular lesions.

It is best treated with isotretinoin (0.5-1 mg/kg daily for 4-5 months).

Chloracne is an acne-like eruption of blackheads, cysts, and pustules associated with exposure to certain halogenated aromatic compounds, such as chlorinated dioxins and dibenzofurans. The lesions are most frequently found on the cheeks, behind the ears, in the armpits and groin region.

Morbihan disease is a rare condition characterized by chronic and persistent erythematous solid edema localized on the face. It is believed to be a complication of rosacea and may occur at any stage of the disease

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-618

questions.text: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome represents hemangiomas with-
questions.solution:
Combination of giant hemangioma, thrombocytopenia, and consumption coagulopathy KMS is an infrequent but potentially fatal complication of rapidly growing vascular lesions in infants

The low platelet count in Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is due to a combination of increased destruction and sequestration of platelets within the expanding vascular tumour.

The tumor here is infantile haemangioma. MC vascular tumor in infants

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1797

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis was started on some treatment by a local practioner. He developed generalized pustules all over his body after stopping treatment. What is the treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
Pustular psoriasis is chracterised by appearance of multiple sterile pustules along with constitutional symptoms.One of the precipitating factor for pustular psoriasis to develop is withdrawal of systemic corticosteroid.

1st line of therapy is etretinate/acitretin, but Methotrexate and cyclosporine are also effective.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-323

questions.text: A 69 year old patient with long standing diabetes mellitus presented with these lesions on the shin. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is asymptomatic.

Patients usually present with shiny, asymptomatic patches that slowly enlarge over months to years. The patches are initially red-brown and progress to yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques. Ulcerations can occur, typically after trauma and occasionally with associated pain. The patient's main complaint is the unsightly cosmetic appearance of the lesions.

Most cases of necrobiosis lipoidica occur on the pretibial area

main findings on histopathology - granulomas, thickening of the blood vessel walls and endothelial cell swelling found in the middle to deep dermis, characteristics shared with diabetic microangiopathy.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1656

choices.text: A hamartoma of eccrine sweat gland

questions.text: A 25 year old lady presented with aymptomatic lesions around the eye. What is the pathology of this disorder
questions.solution:
Syringoma is benign neoplasm with differentiation towards eccrine acrosyringium. Histologically 'tadpole' like morphology of tumour lobules present.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1944

choices.text: Mono benzone ether of hydroquinone is the main chemical cause
Melanocytes present but melanin absent in the patch

questions.text: Which of these is true about the disorder shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Common items from which synthetic leather-/rubber-related leucoderma has been reported are rain shoes, rubber slippers, synthetic leather wallets, watch straps,and rubber gloves. Almost all cases occur when the offending item is in tight apposition against the skin, and is kept there for prolonged periods leading to leaching of the offending chemical.

chemical is a known melanocytotoxic agent and depigmentation.

No melanocytes in the lesion.

The treatment of chemical leucoderma hinges upon the early recognition of the condition (which is usually easy) and cessation of use of products.

Difficult to treat, topical steroids may help but ultimately, surgical methods needed.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1140

questions.text: A 25 year old male had arthritis in right ankle and multiple tender nodules on the shin. He also has fever and malaise for 2 weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Erythema nodosum (EN) (red nodules) is an inflammation of the fat cells under the skin (panniculitis) characterized by tender red nodules or lumps that are usually seen on both shins.
  2. EN is an immunologic response to a variety of different causes.
  3. Crops of tender subcutaneous nodules, associated with fever/malaise/arthritis.
  4. Most common seen in Anterior surface of legs/Shins
  5. Resolve in 2 -4 weeks, with post inflammatory hyperpigmentation
  6. Never ulcerate (contrast with posterior leg and ulceration seen in erythema induratum)

Seen with streptococcal infection(MC infectious association), TB, Sarcoidosis,

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1734

questions.text: A patient presented with photosensitivity, painful blistering of skin, fragile skin and extra hairgrowth on the face and hands. Which of these drugs can be used for treatment ?
questions.solution:
1. Porphyria cutanea tarda is a group of disorders which are characterized by raised porphyrins in the plasma, urine and feces.
  2. Although it is usually acquired, it can also be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. When the disease is acquired, it is generally secondary to liver damage, most typically from alcohol abuse, dialysis
  3. Alcohol and estrogens may also precipitate autosomal dominant porphyria cutanea tarda.
  4. Patients typically have increased hair on the sides of the face and periorificial violaceous discolorations and blisters on the dorsum of the hands that leave scar after healing. (Wolverine facies)
  5. There is marked skin fragility in sun-exposed skin areas.
  6. Urine of these patients show a pink fluorescence under Wood's light.
  7. Patient should avoid alcohol and exposure to direct sun light.
  8. Venesection, the removal of 500 ml of blood every 2 weeks, results in remission - TOC
  9. Chloroquine - oral drug, acts as a systemic sunscreen and anti-inflammatory drug

Patients with pseudo-porphyria secondary to dialysis are treated with erythropoietin in combination with venisection.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-781

questions.text: A 3 months old male infant developed otitis media for which he was given a course of Co-trimoxazole. A few days later, he developed extensive peeling of the skin; there were no mucosal lesions and the baby was not toxic. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome-

The initial event is usually a localized staphylococcal infection (Figure 26.14) [4]. This may be in the skin or at a distant or 'occult' site. A few days later, patients develop fever, irritability and skin tenderness. A widespread erythematous eruption follows which is usually accentuated in the flexures and progresses rapidly to superficial blister formation (Nikolsky positive). The tender skin becomes gathered into folds and, as it shrinks, leaves raw areas which are extremely painful. The condition usually heals within 7-14 days.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition. Pg No- 26.28

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this asymptomatic lesion shown in the image below ?
questions.solution:
• Annular lesions with beaded papules on margins
  • Asymptomatic
  • Seen commonly in Diabetic patient

Palisading granuloma on HPE (most important)

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1650

questions.text: An 8-month old child presented with itchy lesions as shown in image. The siblings also have similar complaints. The treatment of choice is such a patient is:
questions.solution:
The child in this question indicates features of scabies caused because of Sarcoptesscabei. Treatment of choice in scabies is 5% permethrin cream. In adults, its application is usually from the neck down and after 8 to 14 hours of application it is washed off. In children less than 5 years of age and even the elderly, this cream should be applied on the entire skin surface except the eyes. Some other treatment options are also there, such as:

  • 10% Topical crotominton
  • 1% gamma benzene hexachloride
  • 25% Benzyl benzoate
  • Ivermectin

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No.-1506

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown in the image
questions.solution:
True isomorphic phenomena:

  • Lichen planus
  • Vitiligo
  • Psoriasis

Pseudo isomorphic phenomena:

  • Verruca (Warts)
  • Molluscum Contagiosum

Reference: Sanchez DP, Sonthalia S. Koebner Phenomenon. [Updated 2022 Nov 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553108/

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaint of skin lesion as shown in the image. Which of the following nail deformity commonly not seen with this type of skin lesion
questions.solution:
Nail lichen planus is manifested with nail plate thinning, longitudinal ridging, distal nail plate splitting, onycholysis, onychorrhexis, subungual hyperkeratosis, lunular erythematous patches, and pterygium.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No- 197

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disease
Loss of function mutation of F-12 is seen in patients having type III HAE
Associated with mutations of SERPING1 gene
All types of HAE aggravated by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

questions.text: All of the following statements are false regarding hereditary angioneurotic edema except:
questions.solution:
Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE) is associated with mutation in SERPING1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called C1 inhibitor.

Types I and II HAE are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait on chromosome 11q 12.1.

Gain-of-function mutations of F12 that have been described in about 20% of patients with type III HAE.

All types of HAE are aggravated by Oestrogen in contraceptive and hormone replacement therapies

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No- 307

questions.text:
Arrange the following blisters in order from superficial to deep
1. Pemphigus vulgaris
2. Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
3. Junctional EB.
4. Bullous pemphigoid
questions.solution: Reference: Review of Dermatology, Chapter 9. Pg No- 27

questions.text: A patient developed bullae without erythema on elbows, knee & sacral area fib crust formation, scarring & milia. He had no photo sensitivity and negative family history for bullous diseases. On DIF IgG deposition at DEJ with no blood vessel involvement is seen probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) is a rare autoimmune blistering disease in which tense subepithelial blisters appear at sites of trauma. Unlike EB, EBA is not inherited and usually presents in adult life.

EBA blisters tend to be localised to areas that are easily injured such as the hands, feet, knees, elbows, and buttocks. Sometimes there is mucosal involvement with blisters forming in the mouth, nose and eyes.

  • Skin biopsy - this shows the presence of a blister under the epidermis (subepidermal bulla); a variable infiltrate of mixed inflammatory cells in the dermis; and milia cysts and scarring in older lesions.
  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of a skin biopsy - this shows deposition of immunoglobulin (IgG more often than IgM or IgA) and C3 in a line along the dermoepidermal junction. Blood vessels are uninvolved.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No- 523

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with multiple episodes of GTCS was prescribed phenytoin by district hospital physician. After 7 days she presents with a single skin lesion on her arm as shown below. Which of the following will predispose to the condition shown here?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a circular lesion with peripheral erythematous halo after start of anti-epileptic drugs. This is a fixed drug eruption.
  • HLA B1502 allele predisposes to reactions to anticonvulsants HLA B5801 allele predisposes to serious reactions to allopurinol.
  • Fixed drug eruption lesion will reappear at same site after re-administration of drug apart from new ones developing at other sites.

They have a self-limiting course

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No-349

questions.text: A 20 year old soldier presents with fever and dyspnea and CXR shows interstitial pneumonitis. On examination of skin, few lesions are noted, as shown below in the image. Which of the following is the organism is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The etiology of Erythema Multiforme is most commonly Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2 infections and Mycoplasma pneumoniae

Clinically, the typical lesion of the EM is the target lesion, described as a rounded lesion that is regular with three concentric circles and a well-defined border. The peripheral ring is erythematous, sometimes microvesicular; the middle zone is often clearer, oedematous, and palpable, and the center is erythematous, covered by a blister.

Pulmonary signs may also be present, such as a cough and dyspnea. They testify to a respiratory attack most often related to the inducing infection of the EM (mainly due to Mycoplasma pneumoniae).

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No-334

questions.text: A 45-year-old male had multiple hypo aesthetic mildly erythematous large plaques with elevated margins on trunk and extremities. His ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves on both sides were enlarged. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
a. Multiple hypoaesthetic patch on limb and trunk with b/L symmetric Nv thickening are pointing towards lepromatous end of spectrum.

b. BL -presents with hypoesthetic lesions while

c. LL - presents with normoesthetic lesions and late diffuse type of anesthesia(glove and stocking type)

Reference: IAL Textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition. Pg no- 244

questions.text: A young male presented with Hypo anesthetic patch on right forearm. On examination a thickened nerve was palpable. Histopathology shows the following:
questions.solution:
The hallmark of TT is the presence of one to three cutaneous lesions in a patient, called plaques. These lesions are uniformly circular or oval, erythematous/hypopigmented, hairless, scaly, dry and anesthetic.

On histopathological examination, epithelioid histiocytes surround small cutaneous nerves; Langhans giant cells may be seen but without necrosis; the infiltrate may involve the papillary dermis up to the epidermis; may destroy arrectores pilorum muscle; bacilli are usually scarce.

Reference: IAL Textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition. Pg no- 136

questions.text: A 26 yr old man from Bihar comes with juicy looking papules over face and back of neck which were hypopigmented and normoaesthetic with no nerve thickening. History of prolonged fever in childhood was present. What is the treatment ?
questions.solution: Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No- 1474

questions.text: Identify the below condition which is present from birth:
questions.solution:
Congenital melanocytic naevi are most commonly brown or black, present at birth. They are frequently heterogeneous in colour and/or texture. Overlying hair is often not apparent at birth and may develop in the first year. Lesions are usually palpable with increased surface markings.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 75.11

choices.text: Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker. Two weeks later, he developed a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans which exuded clear serum on pressure. Inguinal lymph nodes in the groins were enlarged and not tender. The most appropriate diagnostic test is:
questions.solution:
The incubation period of syphilis is generally given as 9-90 days

The typical primary sore appears as a regularly edged, regularly based, hard and button like ulceration measuring up to 1 cm in diameter. Primary sores are not painful. The ulcer is often surrounded by a narrow, red border, 1-2 mm wide.

Treponema pallidum can be identified from lesions of primary, secondary or early congenital syphilis by dark field microscopy. In primary syphilis, it makes the diagnosis possible before measurable antibodies appear.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 29.21

questions.text: A 22-year old male developed pigmentation over upper chest for the Iast 2 years as shown in image. What is the best treatment modality for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Becker's nevus is a common pigmented dermatosis, usually featured by ipsilateral pigmented patch with hypertrichosis.

Its prevalence can be as high as 2-4% in young males in some regions. It can occur in both males and females either at birth or at adulthood. Although Although lesions are asymptomatic, cosmetic concerns are bothersome. Lasers are the primary approach to treat Becher's nevus.

Reference - Zhong Y, Yang B, Huang L, Elias PM, Man MQ. Lasers for Becker's nevus. Lasers Med Sci. 2019 Aug;34(6):1071-1079. doi: 10.1007/s10103-019-02734-3. Epub 2019 Feb 14. PMID: 30762191; PMCID: PMC6626575.

choices.text: Estimation of IgE levels in blood

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer has itchy erythematous papular lesions on face, neck, 'V' area of chest, dorsum of hands and forearms for 3 years. The most appropriate test to diagnose the condition would be
questions.solution:
This is a case of contact allergic dermatitis and best way to diagnose is patch test to parthenium

Patch Test

  • Description: Detection of antigens responsible for Type IV hypersensitivit

Method:

  • Antigens in standardized dilutions are applied on back if body as occlusions
  • Patches removed after 48 hours and sites marked
  • Inspection is done after 1/2 -1 hour and then at 96 hours
  • Reading: Reaction (erythema/ Edema/ Papulation/ Vesiculation) noted with grading

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 128.53

questions.text: A male child with cryptorchidism presents with large black scales on body flexures. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
X linked ichthyosis-

The disease affects almost exclusively boys. The mothers of affected children frequently report birth complications relating to the presence of the enzyme defect in the placenta. Insufficient cervical dilatation is often found in pregnant women with placental sulphatase deficiency and may cause prolonged delivery necessitating caesarean section or forceps delivery. Directly after birth, most patients present with a very fine scaling or peeling of the skin that often goes unnoticed and soon resolves. At the age of 2-6 months, usually large thick dark brown to yellow brown hyperkeratoses develop covering the trunk, the extremities and the neck.

Deep stromal corneal opacity is a frequent finding if patients undergo an expert ophthalmological examination, but it usually does not affect visual acuity. RXLI may be associated with cryptorchidism in up to 20%, with attention deficit hyperactivity syndrome (ADHD) in up to 40% or with autism in around 25%.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 65.6

choices.text: Tell the patient to avoid sunlight
Follow the lesion for any evidence of growth

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of a mole on her upper back. The lesion is 6 mm in diameter, darkly pigmented, and asymmetric, with a very irregular border. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Melanoma, also redundantly known as malignant melanoma, is a type of skin cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes

A is for Asymmetry.

B is for Border. Melanoma borders tend to be uneven and may have scalloped or notched edges.

C is for Color. Multiple colors are a warning sign.

D is for Diameter : if the size of the lesion is 6 mm or larger.

E is for Evolving. Any change in size, shape, color or elevation, or any new symptom in it, such as bleeding, itching or crusting, may be a warning sign of melanoma.

Any lesion suspicious for melanoma on the basis of the history or clinical examination requires a biopsy to provide a diagnosis and direct appropriate treatment. The ideal biopsy is a prompt, narrow ∼2  mm margin excision of the entire clinically apparent lesion.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 143.23

questions.text: The lesion shown below is seen in:
questions.solution:
The image shows presence of Heliotrope rash suggestive of diagnosis of dermatomyositis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 53.3

questions.text: A patient presented for evaluation of this lesion as seen in the Illustration which has been on his skin for 6 months. The lesion began as a red papule with a thick adherent scale. Since that time, it has progressed to the current pictured lesion with raised borders and scars. There has been no improvement with use of topical glucocorticoids. What is the best course of action for this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE, also called chronic cutaneous LE) is characterized by discrete lesions, most often found on the face, scalp, and/or external ears.
  2. The lesions are erythematous papules or plaques with a thick, adherent scale that occludes hair follicles (follicular plugging).
  3. When the scale is removed, its underside shows small excrescences that correlate with the openings of hair follicles (so called 'carpet tacking'), a finding relatively specific for DLE.

Treatment is focused on control of local cutaneous disease and consists mainly of photoprotection and topical or intralesional glucocorticoids. If local therapy is ineffective, use of aminoquinoline antimalarials may be indicated

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 51.1

questions.text: The following lesion appears on the cheek of a patient, suffering from recurrent bouts of bloods diarrhoea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
a. The image shows erythematous, edematous plaque in a patient with IBD diagnostic of Sweet syndrome.

b. Choice A, Erythema nodosum occurs in up to 15% of CD patient and 10% of UC patients and responds when treatment for bowel inflammation is given. The lesions are red, tender nodules are found on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, calves, thighs and are ruled out as it not managed with potassium iodide.

c. Choice B, Erythema marginatum is seen with rheumatic fever.

d. Choice C, Pyoderma gangrenosum is ruled out as it seen as an ulcer with well-defined margins.

e. Sweet syndrome is febrile neutropenic dermatosis in patients with inflammatory, haematological, visceral malignancy or vaccination.

f. It shows excellent response to systemic steroids and potassium iodide

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 49.7

questions.text: Serpiginous pattern of skin lesion as shown in the image below is characteristically seen in
questions.solution:
Cutaneous larva migrans is a clinical term for a distinctive cutaneous eruption that has numerous causes. The prime features, as the name suggests, are that the lesions creep or migrate, and that they are due to the presence of moving parasites in the skin.

Causes of creeping eruption include Ancylostoma brasiliense, A. caninum.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 33.18

choices.text: It is more malignant than basal cell carcinoma
It occurs more frequently in Fitzpatrick skin type 3-5
It rarely metastasizes to regional lymph nodes
It should be treated by radiation therapy

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with skin lesion seen in the Illustration. She reported a H/O Radiation treatments for Eczema in Hand. Which of the following is True:
questions.solution: Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 142.14

questions.text: Pseudopelade of Brocq shows following feature on histopathology:
questions.solution:
Pseudopelade of Brocq

  • Pseudopelade of Brocq is an idiopathic and slowly progressive form of cicatricial alopecia, clinically presenting
    with multiple small alopecic patches on the vertex and parietal areas, in a pattern that has been defined as
    'footprints in the snow'.
  • Characteristic histopathological feature are:-
  1. A thin epidermis
  2. Complete absence of hair follicles and sebaceous glands
  3. A increased number of fibroblasts in the upper dermis
  4. Fibrotic rims around remnants of hair follicles (Concentric perifollicular lamellar fibrosis)
  5. A sparse inflammatory infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes
  6. Absence of hair bulbs in the subcutaneous fat

About other options

  • Clutching the ball appearance - lichen nidatus
  • Church spire appearance - acrokeratosis verruciformis of Hopf

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 89.41

questions.text: A farmer presented with lesion as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mycetoma


Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains

Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

Causative agent: Pigmented (Dematiaceous fungi)

  • Fonsecaea pedrosoii
  • Phialophora verrucosum

Clinical feature : Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites. MC on foot

Histopathology shows medlar / sclerotic bodies/ copper penny bodies


Treatment: Itraconazole

Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)


Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii

It is diamorphic fungus

There are 3 types:


KOH mount: cigar shaped yeast

Histopathlogy shows 'Asteroid bodies'

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition.

questions.text: A child presented with a sore throat and fever and was prescribed a medicine, after which he followed up with this rash. Which is the causative drug?
questions.solution:
Drugs associated with exanthematic reactions

  • Ampicillin and penicillin
  • Carbamazepine
  • Sulphonamides
  • Phenytoin
  • Non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs
  • Allopurinol

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 118.1

questions.text: The condition seen in the illustration is:
questions.solution:
Rhinophyma the commonest form of Phymatous Rosacea and seen typically in male patients may appear de novo (without preceding inflammatory changes)

Phymatous rosacea is characterised by thickened skin with enlarged pores and irregular surface nodularities. These changes are most commonly found on the nose (rhinophyma), but can occur on the ears, chin and forehead. This subtype is more common in men than women.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought by parents with abdominal pain, joint aches, and a rash on his legs and feet. He does not have a history of frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, or other episodes of abnormal bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The cutaneous findings are typically erythematous, urticarial papules, which may evolve within 24h into palpable purpura with haemorrhage. Urticaria, vesicles, bullae (Figure 102.13 a) and necrotic ulcers.

Renal involvement with IgA vasculitis is common, occurring in approximately 40-50% of patients; 25% have gross haematuria, Proteinuria occurs in 60% of these. Gastrointestinal involvement is common (65%). Painful arthritis is seen in about 75% of patients.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 102.15

questions.text: A child has rash on elbow as shown with family history of asthma.What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Atopic dermatitis(AD), also known as 'atopic eczema', is a type of inflammation of the skin(dermatitis)'.It results in 'itchy', red, swollen, and cracked skin.Clear fluid may come from the affected areas, which often thicken over time.
  • The condition typically starts in childhood with changing severity over the years. In children under one year of age much of the body may be affected. As children get older, the back of the knees and front of the elbows are the most common areas affected.
  • In adults the hands and feet are the most commonly affected areas. Many people with atopic dermatitis develod hay fever or asthma.
  • The cause is unknown but believed to involve genetics, immune system dysfunction, environmental exposures, and difficulties with the permeability of the skin.If one identicaltwin is affected, there is an 85% chance the other also has the condition. While emotional stress may make the symptoms worse it is not a cause. The disorder is not contagious. The diagnosis is typically based on the signs and symptoms.
  • Treatment involves avoiding things that make the condition worse, daily bathing with application of a moisturising cream afterwards, applying steroid creams when flares occur, and medications to help with itchiness. Phototherapy may be useful in some people. Antibiotics (either by mouth or topically) may be needed if a bacterial infection develops.Dietary changes are only needed if food allergies are suspected.
  • AD commonly occurs on the eyelids where signs such as Dennie-Morgan infraorbital fold, infra-auricular fissure, periorbital pigmentation can be seen. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation on the neck gives the classic 'dirty neck' appearance. Lichenification, excoriation and erosion or crusting on the trunk may indicate secondary infection. Flexural distribution with ill-defined edges with or without hyperlinearily on the wrist, finger knuckles, ankle, feet and hand are also commonly seen.
  • Many people with AD have a family history of atopy. Atopy is an immediate-onset allergic reaction (type 1 hypersensitivity reaction) that manifests as asthma, food allergies, AD or hay fever.The pathophysiology may involve a mixture of type I and type IV-like hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Skin creases are involved: flexural dermatitis of fronts of ankles, antecubital fossae, popliteal fossae, skin around eyes, or neck, (or cheeks for children under 10)

  • History of asthma or allergic rhinitis (or family history of these conditions if patient is a child ≤4 years old)
  • Symptoms began before age 2 (can only be applied to patients ≥4 years old)
  • History of dry skin (within the past year)
  • Dermatitis is visible on flexural surfaces (patients ≥age 4) or on the cheeks, forehead, and extensor surfaces (patients<age 4)
  • Medication:- Topical corticosteroids, such as hydrocortisone have proven themselves effective in managing AD. If topical corticosteroids and moisturisers fail, short-term treatment with topical calcineurininhibitors like tacrolimus or pimecrolimus may be tried. Alternatively systemic immunosuppressants may be tried such as ciclosporin, methotrexate, interferongamma-1b, mycophenolate mofetil and azathioprine

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Pg no- 41.17
